title: The Doctrine of Discovery
description: A series of 15th-century papal bulls that gave Christian explorers the right to claim lands inhabited by non-Christians. This doctrine formed the legal and religious basis for the dispossession of Indigenous peoples worldwide and continues to influence U.S. Indian Law.

title: Act of War: The Overthrow of the Hawaiian Nation
description: This film details the 1893 illegal overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom by American businessmen, backed by U.S. Marines. It tells the story from a Native Hawaiian perspective, providing the historical foundation for the modern Hawaiian sovereignty movement.

title: The Fish Wars & The Boldt Decision
description: Chronicles the Pacific Northwest Indigenous civil rights movement of the 1960s-70s, where fishers staged 'fish-ins' to assert their treaty rights. This activism led to the landmark 1974 Boldt Decision, reaffirming tribal sovereignty and co-management of salmon resources.

title: ANCSA: The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act
description: In 1971, ANCSA settled aboriginal land claims by creating a system of Native-owned corporations. This film explores the complex 50-year legacy of this unique experiment in Indigenous self-determination through a corporate model.

title: The Gauntlet: The Fight for Federal Recognition
description: For hundreds of unrecognized tribes, the costly and arduous process of gaining federal recognition is a modern form of political erasure. 'The Forgotten Creeks' tells the story of the Poarch Band of Creek Indians' successful, decades-long fight to have their history seen.

title: The Mission System's Shadow
description: This documentary challenges the romanticized narrative of the California Missions, elevating Native perspectives to expose the system's devastating impact through forced labor, disease, and cultural destruction. It is a call for historical truth-telling.

title: Home From School: The Children of Carlisle
description: The story of the Northern Arapaho's journey to repatriate the remains of their children from the Carlisle Indian Industrial School, whose motto was 'Kill the Indian, save the man.' A powerful look at the brutal legacy of the boarding school system and the healing power of bringing ancestors home.

title: Dawnland: The Indian Adoption Era & ICWA
description: This Emmy-winning film investigates the systematic removal of Wabanaki children from their families by state child welfare services. It follows the first U.S. truth and reconciliation commission, providing essential context for the Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA).

title: Termination and Relocation
description: 'Those Who Remember' captures the voices of Siletz tribal members who lived through the Termination Era, when the U.S. dissolved its relationship with tribes. It tells the story of their fight to reverse this policy and regain federal recognition in 1977.

title: We Hold the Rock: The Occupation of Alcatraz
description: In 1969, a group of Indigenous activists called 'Indians of All Tribes' occupied Alcatraz Island, igniting the modern Red Power movement and forcing a shift in federal policy away from termination and toward self-determination.

title: Standoff at Wounded Knee (1973)
description: Commemorating the 50th anniversary, 'A Tattoo On My Heart' tells the story of the 71-day armed standoff at Wounded Knee through the intimate perspectives of the American Indian Movement (AIM) members who were there, demanding the U.S. honor its treaties.

title: Mni Wiconi: The Standing Rock Protests
description: 'Oyate' frames the 2016 Dakota Access Pipeline (#NoDAPL) protests as an inflection point for human rights. It shows how the movement, rooted in the cry 'Mni Wiconi - Water Is Life,' created a new blueprint for 21st-century Indigenous resistance.

title: Abenaki
description: The Indigenous inhabitants of Wabanahkik ('Dawnland') in New England and Quebec. Today, Abenaki communities are vibrant centers of cultural revitalization, focused on language, traditional arts like basketmaking, and healing from historical traumas like the 20th-century eugenics programs.

title: Absaroka (Crow)
description: The Apsáalooke Nation of the Northern Plains are leaders in the fight for food sovereignty and the protection of their sacred lands in the Yellowstone River Valley. Their culture is renowned for its equestrian skills and matrilineal society.

title: Apache
description: Known for their fierce resistance to colonization, Apache groups were led by figures like Geronimo. Today, their nations celebrate resilience through art, including the legacy of Chiricahua sculptor Allan Houser.

title: Arapaho
description: The Hinono'eino ('Our People') of the Plains are engaged in preserving their unique language and history, including the story of their survival after the Sand Creek Massacre and their life on the Wind River Reservation.

title: Blackfeet (Siksikaitsitapi)
description: A confederacy whose territory stretched across the Northern Plains. They are leaders in conservation, fighting to protect sacred lands like the Badger-Two Medicine area and restoring wild buffalo to their ancestral lands.

title: Caddo
description: A sophisticated agricultural society from the Red River Valley, known for their advanced pottery. Today, they are revitalizing their language and the ancient art of river cane basketry.

title: Cherokee
description: The Cherokee were forcibly removed from their Southeastern homelands on the 'Trail of Tears'. Today, the three federally recognized Cherokee tribes are leaders in media, language revitalization, and grappling with complex questions of citizenship for the descendants of their former slaves, the Freedmen.

title: Cheyenne
description: The Tsitsistas ('the people') were central figures in the Plains Wars. Today, the Northern and Southern Cheyenne nations focus on healing historical trauma, preserving their warrior society traditions, and creating opportunities for youth.

title: Chickasaw
description: Known as unconquerable warriors, the Chickasaw have a thriving sovereign nation in Oklahoma and tell their own stories through their world-class media production company, Chickasaw Films.

title: Comanche
description: Master equestrian warriors who built an empire on the Southern Plains. Today, the nation is healing from the trauma of boarding schools and preserving the legacy of leaders like Quanah Parker.

title: Creek (Muscogee)
description: A confederation from the Southeast. Those who resisted removal remain in Alabama as the Poarch Band, while the Muscogee Nation in Oklahoma fights to protect sacred sites like the Hickory Ground.

title: Delaware (Lenape)
description: The original people of 'Lenapehoking' (the Delaware Valley), who were scattered across the continent by centuries of forced migrations. Today they are revitalizing their language and culture.

title: Flathead (Salish)
description: The Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes of Montana are leaders in tribal governance and are saving their language from extinction through innovative immersion schools.

title: Hopi
description: Living in the oldest continuously inhabited settlement in the U.S. The Hopi have a complex ceremonial life, expressed in their art and the concept of 'Koyaanisqatsi' (life out of balance).

title: Iroquois (Haudenosaunee)
description: The 'People of the Longhouse,' a confederacy of six nations. Their Great Law of Peace is one of the world's oldest participatory democracies and influenced the U.S. Constitution.

title: Kiowa
description: A Southern Plains nation known for their pictorial calendars, the artistic achievements of the 'Kiowa Six' painters, and their fierce resistance led by figures like Satanta.

title: Lakota
description: The westernmost division of the Great Sioux Nation, their history is defined by their defense of the sacred Black Hills and pivotal events like the Battle of the Little Bighorn and the Wounded Knee Massacre. Today, Lakota people are leaders in language revitalization and treaty rights.

title: Navajo (Diné)
description: The largest tribe in the U.S. by land base. The Navajo Code Talkers were crucial to WWII victory, and their culture is known for weaving and silversmithing.

title: Nez Percé
description: The Nimiipuu embarked on a heroic 1,600-mile fighting retreat in 1877, led by Chief Joseph, in an attempt to reach freedom in Canada. Their story is an epic of resistance.

title: Pawnee
description: Known for their earth lodge villages and sophisticated astronomy. The Pawnee Nation is reviving its culture by repatriating and cultivating their ancestral seeds.

title: Pomo
description: An Indigenous people of Northern California renowned for their intricate basketry. Today they are active in the 'Land Back' movement, seeking to restore Indigenous stewardship.

title: Puebloan Peoples
description: A diverse group of nations in the Southwest known for their permanent villages (pueblos). In 1680, they united in the successful Pueblo Revolt to expel Spanish colonizers.

title: Seminole
description: A nation that coalesced in Florida from various Indigenous groups and free Black people. They famously resisted removal in three wars against the U.S.

title: Shawnee
description: A highly mobile people of the Ohio Valley, led by the famed leader Tecumseh who sought to form a pan-tribal resistance to U.S. expansion.

title: Shoshone
description: The Northwestern Band of the Shoshone are the survivors of the 1863 Bear River Massacre. Today, they are reclaiming the massacre site to create a place of healing.

title: Sioux (Oceti Sakowin)
description: The Great Sioux Nation, or Seven Council Fires, includes the Dakota, Lakota, and Nakota. Their history includes the U.S.-Dakota War of 1862, which resulted in the largest mass execution in U.S. history.

title: Zuni
description: A Pueblo people with a unique language, known for their intricate silver inlay jewelry and fetish carvings. Their culture emphasizes a living, evolving continuity.

title: The Breath of Language: Revitalization
description: 'We Still Live Here' tells the astonishing story of the Wampanoag, who brought their language back from extinction after a century of silence. It is a powerful testament to the language revitalization movements sweeping across Indian Country.

title: Reclaiming the Diet: Food Sovereignty & TEK
description: 'Tending the Wild' reveals the sophisticated Traditional Ecological Knowledge (TEK) of California's tribes, who actively managed their lands for millennia. The series showcases the modern movement to decolonize diets by reviving these ancient foodways.

title: Land Back: A Prayer From the Forest
description: 'Pomo Land Back' documents the spiritual and political movement to restore Indigenous stewardship over ancestral lands. It shows that returning land is essential for cultural survival, ecological healing, and restoring balance.

title: A Sacred Identity: Reclaiming Two-Spirit Traditions
description: 'Two Spirits' explores the honored place of integrated genders in many pre-colonial Indigenous societies through the tragic story of Fred Martinez, a Navajo nádleehí. The film documents the contemporary movement to decolonize gender and revitalize these sacred roles.

title: No More Stolen Sisters: The MMIW Epidemic
description: 'Bring Her Home' puts a human face on the Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women (MMIW) crisis. It follows three women as they fight for justice for their relatives, highlighting the grassroots activism led by women at the heart of the MMIW movement.

title: The Front Lines of Climate Change
description: 'Manzanar, Diverted' shows an unexpected alliance of Japanese American elders, Native activists (Paiute and Shoshone), and environmentalists defending their shared landscape in California's Owens Valley from water diversion, linking historical injustices to contemporary environmental battles.

title: Reel Injun: On the Trail of the Hollywood Indian
description: Cree filmmaker Neil Diamond deconstructs the evolution of the 'Hollywood Indian,' critiquing a century of media stereotypes. The film is an insightful and humorous look at the lasting impact of misrepresentation and the power of authentic storytelling.

title: Ishi and the 'Vanishing Indian' Myth
description: 'Ishi, the Last Yahi' chronicles the life of the last known survivor of a genocide, whose story was used to create the myth of the 'Vanishing Indian.' The film serves as a case study in how this narrative erases violent history and legitimizes colonial occupation.
